importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, and marks the release of Cory Doctorow's new book titled 'Enshittification,' which presents a detailed theory about the degradation of internet platforms.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline covers the period from 2023 to 2025, during which the concept of 'enshittification' gained widespread recognition, with the American Dialect Society naming it Word of the Year in 2023 and Merriam-Webster adding it to its dictionary.

keyTakeAways: The term 'enshittification' was coined by Cory Doctorow and describes the devolution of internet platforms from user-friendly, innovative services into exploitative, profit-driven systems that degrade user and business experiences.

Doctorow outlines three stages of enshittification: Stage 1 (user acquisition with attractive offers), Stage 2 (favoring business customers at user expense), and Stage 3 (excessive fees, poor search quality, and data exploitation that harms both users and merchants).

Amazon and Facebook are cited as central examples of enshittification, with Doctorow alleging that Amazon clones products, charges junk fees (up to 51 cents per dollar earned), and degrades search quality, while Facebook manipulates feeds and forces publishers to publish longer excerpts of content.
The core reasons Doctorow identifies for this degradation are lack of competition and weak consumer protection regulations, including the long-standing 'consumer welfare standard' in antitrust law.

Doctorow proposes policy solutions such as 'right-to-exit' regulations (e.g., allowing users to take e-books with them), increased interoperability between platforms (e.g., allowing Android apps on iPhones or cross-platform messaging), and stronger antitrust enforcement to reverse enshittification.

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Author, internet activist, and journalist who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote the book of the same name.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is the central intellectual force behind the theory of enshittification, presenting a detailed analysis of how internet platforms degrade over time, supported by evidence and case studies from major companies like Facebook and Amazon.

namedEntities.name: Enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the devolution of internet platforms into exploitative, profit-driven systems that degrade user and business experiences.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article centers on enshittification as a core theory explaining why platforms like Facebook, Amazon, and Uber have deteriorated in quality, becoming less user-friendly and more extractive over time.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform and technology company that Doctorow alleges has undergone enshittification, particularly through algorithmic manipulation, targeted ads, and forcing publishers to publish content.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Facebook serves as a primary case study in the article, illustrating how a platform evolved from being user-friendly in its early stages to one that prioritizes business profits over user experience.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An e-commerce and technology company that Doctorow claims has engaged in enshittification through product cloning, junk fees, and poor search algorithms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is a central example of enshittification, with Doctorow asserting that the platform’s business model increasingly harms merchants and users through hidden costs and algorithmic manipulation.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ride-sharing platform cited by Doctorow as part of the broader trend of enshittification among internet platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uber is included in Doctorow’s analysis as a representative example of how platforms, in their evolution, shift from user-friendly services to exploitative business models that prioritize profit over value.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that selected 'enshittification' as its Word of the Year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The selection of the term by the American Dialect Society underscores its cultural and linguistic significance, showing that the concept has gained widespread public recognition and acceptance.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dictionary publisher that included 'enshittification' in its dictionary despite the term containing a swear word.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Merriam-Webster’s inclusion of the term reflects its mainstream acceptance and validates the cultural impact of Doctorow’s concept.

namedEntities.name: Planet Money
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An NPR podcast and newsletter series that first published the article and features a segment on antitrust and internet platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Planet Money provides the platform for dissemination of the theory and includes discussion of broader policy implications, such as antitrust reform and consumer rights.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A non-profit research and advocacy organization cited by Doctorow as the source of data showing Amazon sellers lose 45–51 cents per dollar earned on the platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The organization provides the empirical basis for Doctorow's claims about Amazon’s financial impact on merchants, lending credibility to his argument.

namedEntities.name: Consumer Welfare Standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A legal doctrine in antitrust law that evaluates monopolistic behavior based on consumer price increases, not on broader harms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues that this standard undermines effective regulation of platforms and enables exploitative behavior by allowing companies to grow without facing meaningful consequences.

namedEntities.name: Right-to-Exit Regulation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A proposed policy that would allow users to take their data or digital content (e.g., e-books) with them when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This policy is proposed by Doctorow as a direct solution to enshittification, incentivizing platforms to treat users better by making it easier to leave.

namedEntities.name: Interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A technical standard allowing different products or services to work together, such as enabling Android apps on iPhones or cross-platform messaging.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues that companies intentionally limit interoperability to maintain market power, and that stronger regulations could promote fair competition and user choice.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cory Doctorow introduces the concept of 'enshittification' — the degradation of internet platforms from user-friendly, innovative services into exploitative, profit-driven systems — in his new book. He outlines a three-stage process: first, platforms attract users with attractive deals (Stage 1); then, they favor business partners at user expense (Stage 2); and finally, they impose excessive fees, manipulate algorithms, and degrade search quality to extract profits (Stage 3). Facebook and Amazon are cited as key examples, with Doctorow claiming that Facebook manipulates content feeds and Amazon clones products and charges merchants as much as 51 cents per dollar earned. The theory is rooted in a lack of competition and weak regulation, particularly the consumer welfare standard in antitrust law. Doctorow proposes solutions such as 'right-to-exit' regulations and increased interoperability between platforms to reverse enshittification, which has gained momentum in political and consumer advocacy circles, even among conservatives.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
